identified-content.classifier: Health Maintenance Organizations and Managed Care

abstract.p: Dr Harvey I Hurwitz letter on Sept 10 article on companies that are abandoning health maintenance organizations for preferred provider organizations--doctor networks that agree to reduce rates for their services; says that in his 30 years as internist, he has never seen morale of fellow doctors as low as it is today

block.p: A Sept. 10 Week in Review article reports that companies are ''abandoning H.M.O.'s for preferred provider organizations -- doctor networks that agree to reduced rates for their services.'' It also quotes Robert D. Reischauer, president of the Urban Institute, as saying, ''Don't be surprised if this bubble pops, too.''

A Sept. 10 Week in Review article reports that companies are ''abandoning H.M.O.'s for preferred provider organizations -- doctor networks that agree to reduced rates for their services.'' It also quotes Robert D. Reischauer, president of the Urban Institute, as saying, ''Don't be surprised if this bubble pops, too.''

I expect that this bubble will burst and believe there are no cures for health care's ills on the horizon. In 30 years as an internist, I have never seen the morale of my fellow doctors as low as it is today.

Because of heavily discounted payments from managed care companies or plans, doctors must see a large number of patients to stay afloat financially. They must also work at a speed that makes it difficult to care for those patients.
HARVEY I. HURWITZ, M.D. Ossining, N.Y., Sept. 10, 2000
